docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Yugoslav Talks Collapse; NATO to Step Up Bombing NATO and Yugoslavia failed to reach agreement on a Serbian troop withdrawal from Kosovo, and NATO air strikes will be intensified, the leader of the NATO military delegation to the talks in Macedonia, Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Jackson of Britain, said early today. A1 Fighting continued along the border of Kosovo and Albania, forcing about 1,000 people from a northern Albanian town. Many of them were refugees fleeing from fighting for at least the second time. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: These are exquisite days to ride a bike in this all-American, middle-American boyhood home of Mark Twain. Children can ride to school, to the Tom Sawyer Cave a couple miles south of town, to fish on the banks of the Mississippi, to play pitch-and-catch in a park. They can and they did, but they don't anymore. Hannibal's parks, riverbanks and schools are all but barren of bikes. Plastic riding toys cover the lawn of Ya Gotta Have It, which sells secondhand toys, but the few bikes are stored in the back. A recent late-afternoon tour of a subdivision yielded two people on bikes and four riding lawn mowers.

headline.main: No Work for a Bicycle Thief: Children Pedal Around Less

docs.abstract: Bicycle is nearly extinct as symbol of childhood freedom and transportation in United States; fewer than 1 percent of children ages 7 to 15 ride bicycles to school; analysts cite parental fears of crime and traffic, tight scheduling of organized play, television and computer games and disappearing sidewalks; also, many more 16-year-olds are in cars, thanks to abundance of part-time jobs for teen-agers during this time of prosperity; bicycle industry reports robust sales of mountain bikes to mostly adult riders, of soft-saddled 'comfort' bikes to aging baby-boomers and of recumbent bikes that let riders lie back to pedal; over all, industry sales of bikes have fallen from levels of 1970's and been flat at 15 million to 17 million bicycles a year for last decade (M)
docs.snippet: These are exquisite days to ride a bike in this all-American, middle-American boyhood home of Mark Twain. Children can ride to school, to the Tom Sawyer Cave a couple miles south of town, to fish on the banks of the Mississippi, to play...

docs.lead_paragraph: Alana Theriault, who earns less than $1,000 a month working part time as a benefits counselor, is back in school to learn computer programming. Her instructors say she has a special aptitude, and when she gets her certificate soon, she says, she expects to be offered a programming job paying as much as $50,000 a year. But unless Federal law is changed, Ms. Theriault, who is 32, lives in Berkeley, Calif., and is severely disabled, may not be able to take such a job and may have to forfeit the chance to be more financially self-sufficient.

headline.main: Health Benefits Bill Shows Power of the Disabled

docs.abstract: Senate is expected to approve bill that would allow disabled people to retain health benefits under Medicaid and Medicare even if they go to work and earn too much to be entitled to Federal disability benefits to which health insurance is tied; advocates for disabled say bill would be most important measure since Americans with Disabilities Act outlawed discrimination against disabled nine years ago; Pres Clinton urges Congress to approve new measure quickly, so that handicapped will no longer have to choose between working or receiving disability benefits; many disabled people require costly medical attention they could never pay for themselves; measure has broad bipartisan support; no one knows how many people would take advantage of new benefits if they became available; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Alana Theriault, who earns less than $1,000 a month working part time as a benefits counselor, is back in school to learn computer programming. Her instructors say she has a special aptitude, and when she gets her certificate soon, she says, she...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Lois Anne Zook (letter, June 2) says she would happily pay for doctor visits and prescriptions herself if insurance companies would stop stalling on big-ticket items like surgery.
docs.abstract: Prof Alan Meisel letter comments on June 2 Los Anne Zook letter; says US health insurance system is really prepaid health care, and focus should be returned to insuring against catastrophic loss
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Lois Anne Zook (letter, June 2) says she would happily pay for doctor visits and prescriptions herself if insurance companies would stop stalling on big-ticket items like surgery.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A May 31 news article discusses the high divorce rates among families in which one spouse has a long-term disability. Our medical and insurance systems assume that the burden of medical care will be borne by the spouse. Inevitably, this changes the spousal relationship for the worse.

headline.main: How to Help Spouses Who Are Also Caretakers

docs.abstract: Letter by Ellen Pulleyblank, vice chairwoman of Council on Contemporary Families, comments on burden of care for people with long-term disabilities that is borne by their spouses (May 31 article); calls for national program of home health care
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    A May 31 news article discusses the high divorce rates among families in which one spouse has a long-term disability. Our medical and insurance systems assume that the burden of medical care will be borne by the spouse. Inevitably,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Welfare rolls are shrinking more slowly in big cities than elsewhere in their states and, as a result, welfare recipients are increasingly concentrated in urban areas, state and local officials and welfare policy experts say. ''The largest American cities are becoming home to a larger and larger share of the nation's welfare recipients,'' said Bruce Katz, director of the Center on Urban and Metropolitan Policy at the Brookings Institution here.

headline.main: As Welfare Rolls Shrink, Cities Shoulder Bigger Load

docs.abstract: Welfare rolls are shrinking more slowly in big cities than elsewhere in US, so that welfare recipients are increasingly concentrated in urban areas; urban counties that include 30 largest cities have 20 percent of nation's population, but 39 percent of welfare recipients; lagging economies in cities like Philadelphia cited, although some cities, like San Jose, have reduced welfare rolls faster than their states; whites are leaving rolls much faster than blacks and Hispanics, who now outnumber whites two to one (M)
docs.snippet: Welfare rolls are shrinking more slowly in big cities than elsewhere in their states and, as a result, welfare recipients are increasingly concentrated in urban areas, state and local officials and welfare policy experts say.    ''The largest...

keywords.value: WORKFARE AND EMPLOYMENT OF WELFARE RECIPIENTS

docs.lead_paragraph: It is not surprising that almost all the discussion about the upcoming Senate race in New York concerns personalities. The cast of characters is, after all, larger than life. First Lady Hillary Clinton has all but officially announced her candidacy, as has Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. If Mr. Giuliani has to fight for the Republican nomination against Representative Rick Lazio of Long Island, chances are that the Mayor's combative persona will be the focus of that primary as well. But New York is a state with more than its quota of economic and social problems. It deserves a campaign that includes a full discussion of the issues that will affect it in the next millennium.

headline.main: A Script for the Senate Race

docs.abstract: Editorial notes that discussion about upcoming Senate race in New York is focusing mostly on personalities of likely candidates, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani; says state has economic and social problems, and deserves campaign that includes full discussion of important issues; calls on candidates, as they announce, to commit themselves to series of issue-based debates throughout campaign
docs.snippet: It is not surprising that almost all the discussion about the upcoming Senate race in New York concerns personalities. The cast of characters is, after all, larger than life. First Lady Hillary Clinton has all but officially announced her candidacy,...

docs.lead_paragraph: IMAGINE working for a company that bases compensation on family status. If you have a spouse and children, you are paid more, even though single, childless employees seem to work longer hours. Singles hardly ever reach the highest levels of management. And the company does just about everything it can to discourage single employees from mating. Outrageous, no? You'd expect activists to be screaming about such blatant discrimination, and lawyers to be filling the courts with briefs.

headline.main: In Defense Of the Single and Childless

docs.abstract: Article by Daniel Akst, novelist and financial journalist, on unequal treatment of singles compared to married persons in the workplace; says many companies blithely discriminate against childless singles by offering employee benefits that are worth most to people with families; says most workers never claim discrimination for being single and childless; says one reason is that they lack protected status of other groups (M)
docs.snippet: IMAGINE working for a company that bases compensation on family status. If you have a spouse and children, you are paid more, even though single, childless employees seem to work longer hours. Singles hardly ever reach the highest levels of...

docs.lead_paragraph: SHOULDN'T people with mental illnesses, which can destroy lives and families, be entitled to the same amount of insurance coverage as those with physical illnesses? On the face of it, that sounds like a fairly simple question. But as in all things having to do with health care, and especially the often vaguely defined area of mental illness, the issue can be maddeningly complicated.

headline.main: The Nation; Mental Illness Hits The Money Trail

docs.abstract: Tipper Gore, wife of Vice Pres Gore, will open White House conference to draft new health-care policies that would require employers and insurers to provide coverage for outpatient and inpatient mental health comparable to that for other kinds of medical care; few question need for clinical treatment for those with worst mental illnesses; debate now focuses on those whose treatment consumes two-thirds of $80 billion now spent on health-care treatment; this segment includes 'worried well,' as they are called by those who question employment of psychiatric therapy to address less severe emotional distresses and addiction problems; most of this is paid by employer-provided health insurance; concern is that legislation might invite fraud or provide profit incentives to tailor diagnoses and to recruit new pools of patients; photo (M))

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Insurers and Uninsured Put Hospitals in a Squeeze'' (May 9), which looked at hospitals' recent cash-flow problems after years of profitability:
docs.abstract: Letter by Roy W Huntsman on May 9 article on financial problems facing hospitals; says it is time for public to tell third-party payers such as Medicare and insurance companies to pay them less; says for more than 36 years as practice management consultant he has seen high rates charged by hospitals and now the industry is getting dose of its own medicine
